titleStmt.title: Picture Fuzzy Hamacher Aggregation Operators and their Application to Multiple Attribute Decision Making

affiliation.orgName: School of Business Sichuan Normal University Chengdu

analytic.title: Picture Fuzzy Hamacher Aggregation Operators and their Application to Multiple Attribute Decision Making

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: picture fuzzy Hamacher geometric aggregation operators

div.p: In this paper, we investigate the multiple attribute decision making (MADM) problem based on the arithmetic, geometric aggregation operators and Hamacher operations with picture fuzzy information. Then, motivated by the ideal of traditional arithmetic, geometric aggregation operators and Hamacher operations, we have developed some aggregation operators for aggregating picture fuzzy information: picture fuzzy Hamacher aggregation operators, picture fuzzy Hamacher geometric aggregation operators, picture fuzzy Hamacher correlated aggregation operators, induced picture fuzzy Hamacher aggregation operators, induced picture fuzzy Hamacher correlated aggregation operators, picture fuzzy Hamacher prioritized aggregation operators, picture fuzzy Hamacher power aggregation operators. Then, we have utilized these operators to develop some approaches to solve the picture fuzzy multiple attribute decision making problems. Finally, a practical example for enterprise resource planning (ERP) system selection is given to verify the developed approach and to demonstrate its practicality and effectiveness.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Atanassov [1][2] introduced the concept of intuitionistic fuzzy set(IFS), which is a generalization of the concept of fuzzy set [3]. The intuitionistic fuzzy set has received more and more attention since its appearance . Recently, Cuong [30] proposed picture fuzzy set (PFS) and investigated the some basic operations and properties of PFS. The picture fuzzy set is characterized by three functions expressing the degree of membership, the degree of neutral membership and the degree of nonmembership. The only constraint is that the sum of the three degrees must not exceed 1. Basically, PFS based models can be applied to situations requiring human opinions involving more answers of types: yes, abstain, no, refusal, which cant be accurately expressed in the traditional FS and IFS. Until now, some progress has been made in the research of the PFS theory. Singh [31] investigated the correlation coefficients for picture fuzzy set and apply the correlation coefficient to clustering analysis with picture fuzzy information. Son etc. [32][33] introduce several novel fuzzy clustering algorithms on the basis of picture fuzzy sets and applications to time series forecasting and weather forecasting. Thong [34] developed a novel hybrid model between picture fuzzy clustering and intuitionistic fuzzy recommender systems for medical diagnosis and application to health care support systems. Wei [35] proposed the picture fuzzy cross-entropy for multiple attribute decision making problems. Wei [36] utilized arithmetic and geometric operations to develop some picture fuzzy aggregation operators: picture fuzzy weighted average (PFWA) operator, picture fuzzy weighted geometric (PFWG) operator, picture fuzzy ordered weighted average (PFOWA) operator, picture fuzzy ordered weighted geometric (PFOWG) operator, picture fuzzy hybrid average (PFHA) operator and picture fuzzy hybrid geometric (PFHG) operator. Wei et al. [37] proposed the projection models for multiple attribute decision making with picture fuzzy information. Although, Atanassovs intuitionistic fuzzy set theory has been successfully applied in different areas, but there are situations in real life which cant be represented by Atanassovs intuitionistic fuzzy sets. Voting can be a good example of such situation as the human voters may be divided into four groups of those who: vote for, abstain, refusal of voting. Basically, picture fuzzy sets [33] based models may be adequate in situations when we face human opinions involving more answers of the type: yes, abstain, no, refusal. However, all the above approaches are unsuitable to aggregate these picture fuzzy numbers. Hamacher t-conorm and t-norm, which are the generalization of algebraic and Einstein t-conorm and t-norm [38], are more general and more flexible. There is important significance to research aggregation operators based on Hamacher operations and their application to MAGDM problems. Thus, based on Hamacher operations, how to aggregate these picture fuzzy numbers is an interesting topic. To solve this issue, in this paper, we shall develop some picture fuzzy aggregation operators on the basis of the traditional arithmetic [39][40][41], geometric operations [42][43] and Hamacher operations [38,[44][45][46][47][48][49][50]. In order to do so, the remainder of this paper is set out as follows. In the next section, we introduce some basic concepts related to intuitionistic fuzzy set and picture fuzzy sets. In Section 3, we shall propose some Hamacher aggregation operators with picture fuzzy information. In Section 4, we shall present some Induced picture fuzzy Hamacher aggregation operators with picture fuzzy information. In Section 5, we shall present some Hamacher correlated aggregating operators with picture fuzzy information. In Section 6, we shall present some Induced picture fuzzy Hamacher correlated aggregation operators with picture fuzzy information. In Section 7, we shall present some Hamacher prioritized aggregation operators with picture fuzzy in-formation. In Section 8, we shall present some Hamacher Power aggregation operators with picture fuzzy information. In Section 9, based on these operators, we shall present some models for multiple attribute decision making problems with picture fuzzy information. In Section 10, we shall present a numerical example for enterprise resource planning (ERP) system selection with picture fuzzy information in order to illustrate the method proposed in this paper. Section 11 concludes the paper with some remarks.

div.head: Preliminaries 2.1. Picture fuzzy set
div.p: In the following, we introduce some basic concepts related to intuitionistic fuzzy sets and picture fuzzy set.
Definition 2.1. [1][2] An IFS A in X is given by
div.formula: A = { x, µ A (x), ν A (x) | x ∈ X} ,(1)
div.p: where µ A : X → [0, 1] and ν A : X → [0, 1], where, 0 ≤ µ A (x) + ν A (x) ≤ 1, ∀x ∈ X. The number µ A (x) and ν A (x) represents, respectively, the membership degree and non-membership degree of the element x to the set A.

Although, Atanassovs intuitionistic fuzzy set theory [1][2] has been successfully applied in different areas, but there are situations in real life which cant be represented by Atanassovs intuitionistic fuzzy sets. Picture fuzzy sets are extension of Atanassovs intuitionistic fuzzy sets. Picture fuzzy set [33] based models may be adequate in situations when we face human opinions involving more answers of types: yes, abstain, no, refusal. It can be considered as a powerful tool represent the uncertain information in the process of patterns recognition and cluster analysis. Definition 2.2. [33] A picture fuzzy set (PFS) A on the universe is an object of the form
div.formula: A = { x, µ A (x), η A (x), ν A (x) | x ∈ X} ,(2)
div.p: where µ A (x) ∈ [0, 1] is called the "degree of positive membership of A ", η A (x) ∈ [0, 1] is called the "degree of neutral membership of A " and µ A (x) ∈ [0, 1] is called the "degree of negative membership of A ", and µ A (x),η A (x),ν A (x) satisfy the following condition:
div.formula: 0 ≤ µ A (x)+η A (x)+ν A (x) ≤ 1,∀x ∈ X. Then for x ∈ X, π A (x) = 1 -(µ A (x) + η A (x) + ν A (x)
div.p: ) could be called the degree of refusal membership of x in A.

If π A (x) = 0, then the picture fuzzy set reduces to the Atanassovs intuitionistic fuzzy set theory [1][2]. Thus, the Atanassovs intuitionistic fuzzy set theory is a special form of the picture fuzzy set [33]. Cuong et al. [33] also defined some operations as follows.
Definition 2.3. [33] Given two PFEs represented by and on universe , the inclusion, union, intersection and complement operations are defined as follows:
div.formula: 1) A ⊆ B, if µ A (x) ≤ µ B (x), η A (x) ≤ η B (x) and ν A (x) ≥ ν B (x), ∀x ∈ X; (2) A B = {(x, max(µ A (x), µ B (x))), min(η A (x), η B (x))), min(ν A (x), ν B (x))) | x ∈ X}; (3) A B = {(x, min(µ A (x), µ B (x))), max(η A (x), η B (x))), max(ν A (x), ν B (x))) | x ∈ X}; (4) Ā = {(x, ν A (x), η A (x), µ A (x)) | x ∈ X}.

div.head: Hamacher operations
div.p: T-norm and t-conorm are an important notion in fuzzy set theory, which are used to define a generalized union and intersection of fuzzy sets [52]. Roychowdhury and Wang [53] gave the definition and conditions of t-norm and t-conorm. Based on a t-norm (T ) and t-conorm (T * ), a generalized union and a generalized intersection of intuitionistic fuzzy sets were introduced by Deschrijver and Kerre [54]. Further, Hamacher [55] proposed a more generalized t-norm and t-conorm. Hamacher operation [55] include the Hamacher product and Hamacher sum, which are examples of t-norms and t-conorms, respectively. They are defined as follows:
Hamacher product ⊗ is a t-norm and Hamacher sum ⊕ is a t-conorm, where
div.formula: T (a, b) = a ⊗ b = ab γ + (1 -γ)(a + b -ab)(5)
div.p: Especially, when γ = 1 , then Hamacher t-norm and t-conorm will reduce to
div.formula: T (a, b) = a ⊗ b = ab,(7)
T * (a, b) = a ⊕ b = a + b -ab,(8)
div.p: which are the algebraic t-norm and t-conorm respectively; when γ = 2 , then Hamacher t-norm and t-conorm will reduce to
which are called the Hamacher t-norm and t-conorm respectively [54].

div.head: Induced picture fuzzy Hamacher aggregation operators with picture fuzzy information
div.p: Yager and Filev [41] developed the induced OWA (IOWA) operator. The induced OWA operator represents an extension of the OWA operator [40], with the difference that the reordering step of the IOWA operator is not defined by the values of the arguments, but rather by order inducing variables, where the ordered position of the arguments depends upon the values of the. It can be defined as follows.
Definition 4.1.

[41] An IOWA operator of dimension n is a mapping IOWA: R n → R defined by an associated weight vector w = (w 1 , w 2 , • • • , w n ) such that w j > 0 and n j=1 w j = 1, a set of orderinducing variables u i , according to the following formula:

div.head: Hamacher correlated aggregating operators with picture fuzzy information
div.p: However, the above aggregation operators with picture fuzzy information is based on the assumption that the attribute of decision makers are independent, which is characterized by an independence axiom [56][57], that is, these operators are based on the implicit assumption that attributes of decision makers are independent of one another. For real decision making problems, there is always some degree of inter-dependent characteristics between attributes. Usually, there is interaction among attributes of decision makers. However, this assumption is too strong to match decision behaviors in the real world. The independence axiom generally cant be satisfied. Thus, it is necessary to consider this issue.

div.formula: (1) µ(∅) = 0, µ(X) = 1; (2) A ⊆ B implies µ(A) ≤ µ(B), for all A, B ⊆ X; (3) µ(A ∪ B) = µ(A) + µ(B) + ρµ(A)µ(B), for all A, B ⊆ X and A ∩ B = ∅, where ρ ∈ (-1, ∞).

div.head: Numerical example
div.p: In this section, we utilize a practical multiple attribute decision making problems to illustrate the application of the developed approaches. Suppose an organization plans to implement enterprise resource planning (ERP) system (adapted from [65]). The first step is to form a project team that consists of CIO and two senior representatives from user departments. By collecting all possible information about ERP vendors and systems, project term choose five potential ERP systems A i (i = 1, 2, • • • , 5) as candidates. The company employs some external professional organizations (or experts) to aid this decision-making. The project team selects four attributes to evaluate the alternatives: (1) function and technology G 1 , (2) strategic fitness G 2 , (3) vendors ability G 3 ; (4) vendors reputation G 4 . The five possible ERP systems A i (i = 1, 2, • • • , 5) are to be evaluated using the picture fuzzy numbers by the decision makers under the above four attributes(whose weighting vector is ω = (0.2, 0.1, 0.3, 0.4)), and construct the following matrix R = (r ij ) 5×4 is shown in Table 1. In the following, in order to select the most desirable ERP systems, we utilize the PFHWA (PFHWG) operator to develop an approach to multiple attribute decision making problems with picture fuzzy information, which can be described as following.

Step 1. According to Table 1, aggregate all picture fuzzy numbers rij (j = 1, 2, • • • , n) by using the PFHWA (PFHWG) operator to derive the overall picture fuzzy numbers α i (i = 1, 2, • • • , 5) of the alternative. The aggregating results are shown in Table 2(γ = 2).
Step 2. According to the aggregating results shown in Table 2 and the score functions of the ERP systems are shown in Table 3.

Step 3. According to the score functions shown in Table 3 and the comparison formula of score functions, the ordering of the ERP systems are shown in Table 4. Note that ">" means "preferred to". As we can see, depending on the aggregation operators used, the ordering of the ERP systems is slightly different, but the best ERP system is A 3 .
div.formula: PFHWA A 3 > A 2 > A 1 > A 5 > A 4 PFHWG A 3 > A 1 > A 2 > A 5 > A 4
div.p: In order to illustrate the influence of the parameter γ in this example, we use the different value γ in steps 1-3 to rank the ERP systems. The ranking results are shown in Table 5-6. Note that ">" means "preferred to". As we can see from Table 5-6, the aggregation results using the different aggregation parameter γ are slightly different, and the ordering of the ERP systems is also slightly different, but the best ERP system is A 3 . In general, we can take the values of the parameters γ = 1, 2; they are algebraic aggregation operators and Einstein aggregation operators. About the MADM method with PFNs, we can compare with the method proposed by Singh [66], which is an extended correlation coefficient method for PFNs. Here, we shall compare the proposed method with correlation coefficient method for PFNs proposed by Singh [66]. In multiple attribute decision-making environments, the concept of ideal point has been used to help identify the best alternative in the decision set. Although the ideal alternative does not exist in real world, it does provide a useful theoretical construct against which to evaluate alternatives. Hence, we can define an ideal attribute value in the ideal alternative A + .
Then we call

the relative picture fuzzy ideal alternative. Then we can compute the correlation coefficient between the alternative and relative picture fuzzy ideal alternative by the Eq.( 15) proposed by Singh [66]. We can get the following result: The ranking result is:
div.formula: A 3 A 2 A 1 A 5 A 4 .
div.p: Or, we can compute the correlation coefficient between the alternative and relative picture fuzzy ideal alternative by the Eq.( 16) proposed by Singh [66]. We can get the following result:

div.head: The ranking result is:
div.formula: A 3 A 2 A 1 A 5 A 4 .
div.p: Obviously, there are almost the same ranking results of these methods proposed in this paper. This further verifies the effectiveness of the proposed methods. As mentioned above, the existing information aggregation operators based on the Hamacher operations for IFS have some limitations and are not able to represent the full information about the situation. PFS is a further generalization of the IFS. So the PFS contains more information (degree of positive membership, degree of neutral membership, degrees of negative membership and degrees of refusal membership) than IFS (both membership degree and non-membership degree). Thus, the information aggregation operators based on the Hamacher operations for PFSs can be considered as a further generalization of the information aggregation operators of Atanassovs IFSs [28][29]. Also the proposed information aggregation operators reflect the amount of information expressed by the degree of positive membership, neutral membership and negative membership and the reliability of the information expressed by refusal membership.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, we investigate the multiple attribute decision making (MADM) problem based on the arithmetic, geometric aggregation operators and Hamacher operations with picture fuzzy information. Then, motivated by the ideal of traditional arithmetic, geometric aggregation operators and Hamacher operations, we have developed some aggregation operators for aggregating picture fuzzy information: picture fuzzy Hamacher aggregation operators, picture fuzzy Hamacher geometric aggregation operators, picture fuzzy Hamacher correlated aggregation operators, induced picture fuzzy Hamacher aggregation operators, induced picture fuzzy Hamacher correlated aggregation operators, picture fuzzy Hamacher prioritized aggregation operators, picture fuzzy Hamacher power aggregation operators. Then, we have utilized these operators to develop some approaches to solve the picture fuzzy multiple attribute decision making problems. Finally, a practical example for enterprise resource planning (ERP) system selection is given to verify the developed approach and to demonstrate its practicality and effectiveness. In the future, the application of the proposed aggregating operators of PFSs needs to be explored in the decision making [67][68][69][70][71][72][73][74][75][76][77][78], risk analysis and many other uncertain and fuzzy environment [79][80][81][82][83][84][85][86][87][88][89][90].
